name: 施欣文
objective:
COURSE DESCRIPTION
This course is designed for the high school teacher and for any graduate student who wants a thorough background in the history of American literature from 1492 to the present. Texts may include stories recorded from oral tradition, letters, autobiography, novels, poems, short stories, plays, children’s literature, and/or historical documents. Some texts will be read outside of class; others will be read/acted in class, allowing students to come away with practical teaching ideas for their own classes. This course, instead of culminating in a major seminar paper, is graded based on sample teaching demonstrations, shorter writing assignments, and student participation.

COURSE GOALS
The goals of this class are two-fold. First, I want you to enjoy reading (or revisiting) some of the best-known works of American literature. Thus, the first goal of the course is knowledge and art for its own sake. Secondly, if you are a teacher, I want this course to serve as a means for you to reflect on how you can integrate American literature into your teaching.

scorePolicy:
GRADING AND OTHER POLICIES

Grade Percentages:
I may modify these grade weights at my discretion. If I do so, I will let you know. 

Teaching Reflections and Reading Quizzes: 30%
Informal Teaching Presentations and Class Participation: 30%
Formal Teaching Presentations: 25%
Final Teaching Reflection Paper: 15%

Grading Criteria:
A　　Superior work. Achievement that is outstanding relative to the level necessary to meet course requirements.

B　　Achievement that is significantly above the level necessary to meet course requirements.

C 　　Achievement that meets the course requirements in every respect. 

D 　　Achievement that fails to meet fully the course requirements. 

F 　　Achievement that is not worthy of credit. The only way to outright fail this course is through lack of effort and/or plagiarism. The student may not participate in classroom work. Assignments are either (a) completed but not completed at a level of achievement that is not worthy of credit; (b) frequently late, thereby lowering the grade too significantly to give the student a chance to pass; or (c) never completed at all. 



ASSIGNMENTS
‧　　Reading Quizzes. (If we have a reading assignment, you may have a quiz on it. These are open-note but not open book. Take good notes! Quizzes may not be made up, but your lowest score will be dropped.)
‧　　Teaching Demonstrations. Each student will prepare informal teaching demonstrations (in groups—discussed in class) and formal teaching demonstrations (done individually). You will select the date and topic for your individual teaching demonstrations. 
‧　　Teaching Reflections. Students will write informal reflections on how they would teach a particular work that we study and one formal reflection at the end of the course. 
‧　　Reading Notebook. As you do the reading, jot down any questions or comments you had on the reading. Write a few quick notes about what interested you most about the text (as related to the course themes). Include page numbers and one or two passages we might look at. You might consider these questions or choose another:  

a).  What was the most interesting/intriguing aspect of the day’s reading?
b).  Did you find anything about the reading disturbing, upsetting, or annoying?  Why?  Why does the text include these details?  
c).  How does this text appear to respond to its own time, to history, and/or to the other texts we have read?  
d).  What approaches would you use to teach this work, sections of this work, or information about this work to your class? (If you’re not a teacher, imagine an age-level and think about how you would teach the work.)
materials:
PARTICIPATION

Your participation is key to the success of this course. Please try to make productive statements or ask interesting questions in class each week, and be sure to stay on task during group work. Someone with a high grade in participation shows a thorough engagement with the course readings and visual media, speaks only English in class and takes notes almost exclusively in English, jots down questions in a notebook while reading in order to bring these questions up in class discussion, develops original and creative teaching presentations, participates in the presentations of others, frequently makes thoughtful contributions that raise the level of our class discussion, takes notes in class, is trustworthy, takes academic honesty seriously, stays focused and on-task during class periods, is helpful and engaged during in-class workshops, interacts positively and tactfully with other class members, and reads with expression and enthusiasm. 

If you are worried about your level of participation, please see me. Participation is not how much you say or how smart you can show me you are: contribute in ways that help you and the people around you learn. Know that thoughtful questions are quite as valuable as other kinds of participation.
